results.title: Victoria: 100 years of progress
results.brief_description:
This documentary looks in detail at the history and development of Melbourne, using artist’s sketches and filmed footage to depict the history of Melbourne. Some items include the Manchester Unity Building, cars of the era travelling down St Kilda Road, St Kilda Beach, a brief history of the Princes Bridge, the Royal Botanic Gardens, Geelong and industries and transport existing in 1934. Also includes footage of the opening of Parliament.

Includes archival footage of early transport-cars; shipping; rail (Flinders Street Station); Prince’s Bridge; St. Kilda Beach; Anzac Parade; Flemington Race Course. Arrival of the Duke and Duchess of York for the first opening of Federal Parliament 1901. Also featured: scenes of the city: Collins and Swanston Streets; Melbourne Town Hill; The Exhibition Building; Parliament House and large private homes in the suburb of Toorak. Reference is made to agricultural and pastoral industries - wheat; wool production; fruit growing and tanning in Mildura. Three masted sailing vessels plus a farewell for the ocean liner Strathnaver. Finally, a re-enactment of gold mining/panning and heralding the first one hundredth birthday of the settlement of Melbourne
[SOURCE: NFSA Collection catalogue)

results.title: Victoria Howlett: potter
results.creator_credit: Victorian Film Corporation, Nina Syme and Terry McMahon
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
Victoria Howlett regards her pottery as a reflection of her personality, her travels and her various experiences. She finds inspiration for her work in nature and approaches her tasks very systematically.

results.title: Victoria changing faces changing places
results.brief_description: This short documentary addresses the issues that surround Victoria’s growing population, whilst also probing the past and how migration helped shaped the current demographic. Using voice-over narration, this features an array of archival footage to examine the underlying drivers of population growth, with a view to understanding how the community is changing, and the what the future is likely to hold for Victoria.

results.title: Victoria's first settlers

results.brief_description: The state historian of Victoria Mr Bernard Barrett talks to Trevor Lunn about Victoria’s Aboriginal past, the first British visitors, sealers and whalers and the settlements at Portland and Melbourne.

results.title: Victoria's Energy
results.creator_credit: Dept of Minerals and Energy AV Workshop
results.brief_description:
“Victoria’s energy” uses stills to analyse Victoria’s energy position during 1980-81.

See also Related Title “Energy conservation in the home” which provides useful information on the ways in which energy can be saved within the household.

results.title: Victoria
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Holiday”.
Rich in history and culture, Victoria also boasts a fine selection of food and spectacular natural landscapes. Melbourne’s main attractions open the program including trams, tree-lined boulevards, splendid buildings and magnificent gardens. Its country and coastal regions offer visitors a diverse range of activities from horse riding in the Great Dividing Ranges, experiencing the gold rush at Sovereign Hill, ‘cruising’ Lake Eildon, visiting Flagstaff Hill Maritime Museum, relaxing at Daylesford and Hepburn Springs, rock-climbing at Mount Arapiles and for the gourmet traveller a residential cooking school at Howqua Dale.

results.title: Victor/Victoria
results.creator_credit: Ladbroke Entertainment, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Blake Edwards and Tony Adams
results.brief_description: Sparkling, ultra-sophisticated entertainment from Blake Edwards. This story is based on a 1933 German comedy film “Viktor und Viktoria” written and directed by Rheinhold Schunzel. Set in Paris in 1934, it is the tale of a down-on-her luck chanteuse, played by Julie Andrews. Also suffering a temporary career lapse is tres gai nightclub entertainer (Robert Preston), who remakes her as a man who in short order becomes celebrated as Paris’s foremost female impersonator. In the process she snags the attentions of a Chicago nightclub owner (James Garner). He, however, has a small problem - is it a he or a she who has stolen his heart? 1982 Academy Award for Best Original Score (Henry Mancini). Academy Award nominations for Best Actress (Julie Andrews), Supporting Actor (Robert Preston), Supporting Actress (Lesley Anne Warren), Screenplay Adaptation, Costume Design and Art Direction.
